overview: This measure appropriates funds for the Judiciary for the 2025–2027 biennium. [2] The resource requests center around funding to make permanent or expand three Specialty Courts on O‘ahu, to fully staff the new Wahiawā District Court that will open during this biennium, an additional District Court Judge and support staff in Kona, cybersecurity and critical technology costs, funding for the Criminal Justice Research Institute (CJRI), and restoration of funding for essential staffing that was defunded during the early part of the COVID-19 pandemic. [2] The purpose of this measure is to appropriate funds for the 2025-2027 fiscal biennium for certain operating expenses of the Judiciary. [3]
appropriations: The Judiciary requests additional operating resources in the amount of $6.17M in FY 2026, and $6.25M in FY 2027. [2] The Judiciary also requests a total of $9.9M (from testimony) in bond funds for capital improvement projects in FY 2026. [2] The Committee on Finance is requested to consider authorizing $7,000,000 (HB400_HSCR286_.htm.txt) in lump sum general obligation bond funds for capital improvement projects for Judiciary facilities, including an additional cost of $2,000,000 (HB400_HSCR286_.htm.txt) to relocate the Children's Justice Center. [3]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Judiciary’s resource requirements are based on current circumstances and projected resource needs for the future. [2] The request for additional operating resources is an addition of approximately 3% to the Judiciary’s operating budget. [2] Many requests are to continue resources for programs and positions that are set to expire, such as the Women's Court Pilot Project and the Criminal Justice Research Institute. [2]
agency_impact: The Judiciary requests additional operating resources in the amount of 17.0 permanent FTE and 1.0 temporary FTE. [2] Nine of the 18 requested positions are to continue current staffing for programs like the Women’s Court Pilot Project and the CJRI. [2] The remaining requested positions will significantly expand capacity to certain operations, such as fully staffing the new Wahiawā District Court and adding a District Court Judge in Kona. [2]
economic_impact: The Women’s Court was created to address the rapid growth in the incarceration of women by providing an alternative to incarceration and to aid the participants in bettering their economic conditions and life circumstances. [2] The DWI Court Program seeks to reduce recidivism among repeat and high-risk offenders by addressing the underlying cause of impaired driving. [2] The bill also includes critical funding for civil legal services to low- and moderate- income individuals in Hawai‘i. [2]
policy_impact: This measure will establish a permanent Women’s Court, as the three-year pilot project is set to expire at the end of FY 2025. [2] It also seeks to make the Driving While Impaired (DWI) Court Program permanent, which was initially supported by federal funding. [2] The bill continues resources for the Criminal Justice Research Institute (CJRI), which was established by Act 179 (SLH 2019). [2]
revenue_sources: The Judiciary requests additional operating resources and a total of $9.9M (from testimony) in bond funds for capital improvement projects in FY 2026. [2] Testimony requests an additional $1,000,000 (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt) increase in the budget line-item for statewide civil legal services. [2] The Committee on Finance is requested to consider authorizing $7,000,000 (HB400_HSCR286_.htm.txt) in lump sum general obligation bond funds for capital improvement projects. [3]

operating_revenue_impact: Changes to the federal funding and policy landscape require additional support for Hawaiʻi’s legal services providers. [2] Recently, there have been dramatic reductions in available federal funds for victims of crime and domestic-violence survivors. [2] The testimony does not specify other impacts on operating revenue. [2]
capital_expenditure_impact: The Judiciary requests CIP bond funds totaling $9.9 (from testimony) million for FY 2026 to address critical needs. fiscal_implications_after_6_years: Securing permanent funding would allow the DWI Court Program to continue and grow. [2] The requests to establish a permanent Women's Court and restore funding for numerous permanent positions imply ongoing operational costs beyond the 2025-2027 biennium. [2] The new Wahiawā District Court, set to open in Spring 2026, will also require sustained funding for staffing and operations in subsequent years. [2]
